newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia gas industry blasts new competition code.
newsitem.headline: Australia gas industry blasts new competition code.

text.p: Australia's gas industry on Tuesday attacked a new competition code being prepared for the nation's emerging gas market as a threat to profitability.

On the eve of a landmark meeting of gas-market players on Wednesday to sign off on a draft code, the Australian Gas Association (AGA) said the new document was in some ways worse than an original draft released eight months ago.
"We think 'Mark II' as it stands, yes, is a major infringement of the industry's property rights and earnings capacity," AGA chairman Greg Harvey told Reuters.
"That's where we think the present draft has gone backwards," he added.
The code seeks to set up a regulatory framework which allows gas to be traded freely and fairly via Australia's gas pipelines, most of which are owned by private-sector operators.

The code was to have been finalised by mid-1996, but gas producers, distributers and users, as well as state and national governments, have failed to reach complete agreement, stalling progress toward the goal of a national spot market in gas.
The original draft code, released in September, was rejected by the AGA as heavy handed and sent back to the drawing board.
The AGA, which represents gas producers and the big ulitities which own gas piplines, said the original code handed too much power over access arrangements to regulators.
The AGA's Harvey, who is a member of the official Gas Reform Implementation Group overseeing the code's development, on Tuesday said he had similar criticisms of the latest draft.
"It's our assets that are on the chopping block," he said.
"The question really revolves around what matters the regulator should be allowed to take into account in determining values and reference tariff rates," he added.
A source close to the official reform group's discussions said that, unlike the original draft code, the new draft seeks to establish access tariffs via a competitive bidding process.
But Harvey said regulators were still in ultimate control of access arrangements under the new draft code.
"Our concern is that in trying to speed up the process, insufficient attention is being given to the fundamentals of this whole third-party-access process...," he said.
"We are finding the powers of the regulator enshrined in a way the industry finds very disturbing."
The gas reform group has set itself a new timetable of end-1997 for the implementation of the code, an essential step before a truly competitive gas market can develop in Australia.
The group plans to publish the code for public comment and consultation from late next week, but a gas industry source said it was unlikely the code would succeed without AGA support.
"Most of the code has been agreed by the group," the source said. "There are a few areas that still haven't been resolved. Tomorrow's meeting will hopefully resolve these."
